fb177866b713.title: The Rocket Doesn’t Come With a Moral Compass

content.subtitle: We all know the Zuckerbergian myth of dropping out of college, hungrily and foolishly, for glory, risk, and the promise of scalable impact…

virtuals.snippet: We all know the Zuckerbergian myth of dropping out of college, hungrily and foolishly, for glory, risk, and the promise of scalable impact…
virtuals.subtitle: We all know the Zuckerbergian myth of dropping out of college, hungrily and foolishly, for glory, risk, and the promise of scalable impact…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
and a big payout. The landing page for the $100,000 Thiel Fellowship plays into this narrative: “Pursue ideas that matter instead of mandatory tests. Take on big risks instead of big debt.” ¶

Certainly the person taking this path is betting big on wild success when they jump off of the university track. But there’s a subtler bet: The bet that along the way, the startup will be a better teacher than the university experience they are foregoing.

paragraphs.text: The Rocket Doesn’t Come With a Moral Compass

content.subtitle: Drop the rockstar ego. Pairing is a duet, and you are an accompanist.

virtuals.snippet: Drop the rockstar ego. Pairing is a duet, and you are an accompanist.
virtuals.subtitle: Drop the rockstar ego. Pairing is a duet, and you are an accompanist.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Programming, like any art practice, is a performance. Our code reflects the physical and virtual environment it was created in, the culture and social weather of the team, the constraints of the toolchain and the target architecture, and the mood and facility of the performer at moment of strike. ¶

We often imagine a solo act. It’s 2am and our hero works at a laptop at a small desk in a dark bedroom.

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: How to pair program

paragraphs.name: previewSubtitle
paragraphs.text: Drop the rockstar ego. Pairing is a duet, and you are an accompanist.

4a25d5e24966.title: Death by a thousand great ideas

content.subtitle: At first, my co-founder and I felt like we could do anything. We hadn’t set out with an idea — it was just, “Let’s start a company!”

virtuals.snippet: At first, my co-founder and I felt like we could do anything. We hadn’t set out with an idea — it was just, “Let’s start a company!”
virtuals.subtitle: At first, my co-founder and I felt like we could do anything. We hadn’t set out with an idea — it was just, “Let’s start a company!”
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Originally published on my personal website in April 2012. ¶

found·er¹ (noun)
a person who establishes an institution or settlement.
the excited founders of a Silicon Valley startup ¶

At first, my co-founder Rahmin and I felt like we could do anything. We hadn’t set out with an idea — it was just, “Let’s start a company!” We’d found each other through a shared interest in continuing education, but we were interested in taking six months without committing to a specific path.

f196a5a8bfd3.title: How Multi-User Dungeons taught me to program

content.subtitle: “Mom, what do you want me to write? Just tell me and I’ll write a program for you.” That was me at 9, urgently tugging at my mom’s pant leg…

virtuals.snippet: “Mom, what do you want me to write? Just tell me and I’ll write a program for you.”
virtuals.subtitle: “Mom, what do you want me to write? Just tell me and I’ll write a program for you.” That was me at 9, urgently tugging at my mom’s pant leg…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
. ¶

I don’t remember what, if anything, I ended up writing in BASIC on our Timex Sinclair computer, but I do remember wanting to be taken seriously — wanting to make something that would be useful to someone. I think my dad bought that computer on a whim out of a mail order catalog, which was surprising as he’s not much of a gadget guy. We hooked it up to an old 8" black and white portable TV we had.

content.subtitle: Recently I became a victim of a bug that has been in Google’s code for so long that if you had started a degree program in Computer Science…

virtuals.snippet: Recently I became a victim of a bug that has been in Google’s code for so long that if you had started a degree program in Computer Science…
virtuals.subtitle: Recently I became a victim of a bug that has been in Google’s code for so long that if you had started a degree program in Computer Science…
virtuals.emailSnippet:
back when this bug was introduced, you could have graduated by now and gotten a QA job at Google where you might have the honor of fixing it. ¶

Let’s back up a bit though. I’m the proud owner of 850GB of data. 20 years worth of photos, videos, emails and other bric-a-brac. I’ve been backing it all up for years on a handful of drives, and that works well enough. ¶

But any good backup strategy includes off-site redundancy.

82e275c8764f.title: “The Art of Computer Programming” by Donald Knuth

content.subtitle: Bill Gates doesn’t think most people can finish this book. I gave it a shot.

virtuals.snippet: Bill Gates doesn’t think most people can finish this book. I gave it a shot.
virtuals.subtitle: Bill Gates doesn’t think most people can finish this book. I gave it a shot.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
‘The Art of Computer Programming’ by Donald Knuth ¶

Some books look so beautiful on the shelf. Not only for their aesthetic virtues, but for what their spines say about the owner. The four hardbound volumes of Donald Knuth’s “The Art of Computer Programming” — all snug in their dark purple case — send a clear message: Step aside, Muggles, because you’re in the presence of a Real Programmer. A Serious Practitioner of Computer Science.

paragraphs.text: “The Art of Computer Programming” by Donald Knuth

b1ae9816ccac.title: Review: The food table at Root Division’s MFA NEVER exhibition opening

content.subtitle: Long spared from critical dialog, it’s finally time to address the food at art openings.

virtuals.snippet: Long spared from critical dialog, it’s finally time to address the food at art openings.
virtuals.subtitle: Long spared from critical dialog, it’s finally time to address the food at art openings.
virtuals.emailSnippet: Drawing upon art history and contemporary culture, the food table at the art opening for MFA NEVER in San Francisco was a commentary on deception and artifice, held against the beauty of the natural world. A marvelous bricolage, so economical in its conveyance of meaning. Crudités were served on a tray topped with white paper doilies. The faux silver tray barely attempted to mask its true plastic materiality, mocking the ostentatiousness of contemporary art culture.

paragraphs.text: Review: The food table at Root Division’s MFA NEVER exhibition opening

45ca45748767.title: What we can learn from tidying

content.subtitle: A one-click bottleneck has formed in the circulation of products through our economy. Can tidying save us?

virtuals.snippet: A one-click bottleneck has formed in the circulation of products through our economy. Can tidying save us?
virtuals.subtitle: A one-click bottleneck has formed in the circulation of products through our economy. Can tidying save us?
virtuals.emailSnippet:
This is the second post in a series about urban infrastructure and climate change. The first was about laundry. ¶

It was late in the evening and my partner and I were sitting alone on the bare floor of our living room. We had just wrapped up a week of tidying our two-bedroom apartment, and we felt disoriented and exhausted. Having combed through every one of our belongings, like some desert island survivor scenario, we had carefully chosen the items that we would take with us and those we…

6628d85828b3.title: The past and future of laundry

content.subtitle: and how we could save billions of gallons of water.

virtuals.snippet: and how we could save billions of gallons of water.
virtuals.subtitle: and how we could save billions of gallons of water.
virtuals.emailSnippet:
Laundry ¶

This is the first in a series of articles about urban infrastructure and climate change. ¶

Any good trip abroad will highlight things in our lives that we take for granted. In October 2015, I travelled from San Francisco to the Philippines for some real talk about laundry with my Filipino friend Imman. It was one of my favorite conversations of the year — a moment when a seemingly small cultural difference unraveled into something bigger about technology and urban planning.

paragraphs.name: previewTitle
paragraphs.text: The past and future of laundry

paragraphs.name: previewSubtitle
paragraphs.text: and how we could save billions of gallons of water.

306f4b07f162.title: It’s 2005, and You’re an Engineer at Volkswagen

content.subtitle: Your boss wants that emissions control code done yesterday. What will you do?

virtuals.snippet: Your boss wants that emissions control code done yesterday. What will you do?
virtuals.subtitle: Your boss wants that emissions control code done yesterday. What will you do?
virtuals.emailSnippet:
It’s 2005, and you’re an engineer at Volkswagen. ¶

The Iraq War is still on. Kanye’s Late Registration just hit the streets. And you — you are working as an engineer in the engine development department at Volkswagen. Now let’s play out a fictional thought experiment. ¶

Your team writes the complex engine software that balances intake, exhaust, and timings under a variety of conditions, trading off performance, fuel economy, and emissions control.
